title: 109_hr5472
content: The Act is titled the "National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program Reauthorization Act of 2006". It pertains to the reauthorization of the National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program. Title XV of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 300k et seq.) is amended to update the year from 2000 to 2020. A new section is added for a demonstration project allowing the Secretary to waive certain requirements for up to 5 states to leverage private funds. The new section allows the Secretary to waive requirements for up to 5 states to leverage private funds for services described in section 1501(a). States must demonstrate how they will use the waiver to maintain or expand screening and follow-up services. States must also submit a plan for maintaining the level of activities carried out. The Secretary can waive requirements for up to 5 states to use private funds for services in section 1501(a). States must show how they will maintain or expand screening services and submit a plan for ongoing activities. Granting a waiver should not reduce services for women or affect their quality. The Secretary can grant waivers for up to 2 years, with a possible 2-year extension upon State request. The waiver can be extended for an additional 2-year period based on performance review if it is determined that without it, there would be barriers to enrolling qualifying women. The waiver can be extended for up to 2 years, with a possible 2-year extension upon State request. The State must show that the waiver will not reduce the number of women receiving services or lower their quality. The waiver can be extended for up to 2 years, with a possible 2-year extension upon State request. The State must maintain the average annual level of State fiscal expenditures for specified services and activities for the 2 years of the waiver at a level not less than the preceding year. Reporting requirements include detailing the total amount of dollars. The curr_chunk describes the total amount of dollars leveraged annually from private entities in States receiving a waiver, the percentage of the grant expended on specific services, the number of States receiving waivers annually, and details on how the waiver funds are used. The curr_chunk provides details on the number of women receiving services before and after a waiver, state fiscal expenditures for services, and limitations on the use of waiver funds. The curr_chunk defines terms such as 'Indian tribe,' 'tribal organization,' and 'State' in relation to the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The curr_chunk revises evaluations of state compliance with specific program requirements and grant conditions under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The curr_chunk amends funding allocations for the National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program, increasing the amounts for fiscal years 2007 to 2009. The curr_chunk states funding amounts of $255,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $255,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, and $275,000,000 for fiscal year 2011. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on December 9, 2006. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
